1.summary: Traditional or simplified? New or old? Pen or pencil? Figuring which way to write Mandarin Chinese characters can be tricky at time for learners of the language. People in mainland China use the simplified system, while those overseas may use traditional script instead. Let's dive into why this has happened and cover some essential basics.

content.lead: The main difference between simplified and traditional chinese is the composition of their characters. Pronounciation and meaning remain unaffected when translating meanings between character versions: the change can be considered more of a comestic than linguistic. Also, since there is an 80% overlap between simplified and traditional characters, learning to identify different versions of the same character is quite easy to pin-point. Meaning if you want to focus from now on exclusively simplified chinese, you won't have to relearn over two thousand characters again. Below are some examples ( top set are simplified versions of the respective, bottom characters! )
content.explanation: Chinese simplified characters were created during the mid-20th century due to China having a poor literacy rate amongst its citizens. This was mainly due of how complicated and nuanced tradtional chinese characters or 'hanzi' are by nature. The government of the People's Republic of China promoted and encouraged the usage of the simplified variant since the 1950's, and has official become the main scripting language of mainland China, Malaysia, and Singapore. The main form of simplification is simply reducing the strokes of characters that were commonly used in day to day usage. Above are some simplified versions of characters.

content.lead: Again the main reason simplified characters are created was because of character complexity, particularly how many individual strokes where needed to write a character. For small to medium size characters, this was not a particularly glaring issue. However, for characters with over ten stroke counts, the complexity starts building up gradually. Notice if you can spot the difference between the two versions of saying 'hello' in chinese. The first xiè is written in tradtional script, while the second is simplified.
content.explanation: The traditional way of writing xiè xiè ( thanks ) has total of 17 strokes per character... That's a lot of strokes! And what's worse is that xiè is also a commonly used word, so chances are you are problably going write it out multiple times throughout the day. Simplified chinese comes in to reduce the required overhead of writing common characters while still retaining their instrinsic meaning. In this case, by changing the radical of xiè to a simplified version, we reduce the stroke count to just 12 per character.
